definition[0]: sure that something will happen in the way that you want or expect
example[0]: We are confident next year’s profits will be higher.
example[1]: He is quietly confident that there will be no problems this time.
example[2]: The Prime Minister appeared relaxed and confident of winning an overall majority.
example[3]: The company is confident of success.
example[4]: I feel quite confident about the future.
definition[1]: sure that you have the ability to do things well or deal with situations successfully
example[5]: Despite her disability, Philippa is very confident.
example[6]: He began to read in a calm confident voice.
example[7]: I feel much more confident about myself and my abilities these days.
example[8]: It is not possible to give a confident answer to the question of whether the delay was unreasonable.
example[9]: We are confident we have done nothing wrong.
example[10]: He began to feel confident that Zaborski was only guessing.
example[11]: I’m quite confident about my English
bad_example[0]: I’m quite confident of my English
explanation[1]: You are confident of victory or success, or confident of doing something
example[12]: The team is confident of victory
example[13]: The team is confident of winning
definition[3]: sure that you have the ability to do something well or deal with situations successfully
example[14]: She seemed confident that she would pass.
example[16]: George was very confident about his abilities as a writer.
example[17]: Baldwin is confident of victory in this year’s senate race.
definition[4]: confident, and not shy or nervous in social situations
example[18]: Jess was only 12, but she was very self-confident.
example[19]: He was very self-assured and spoke without notes.
example[20]: I eventually became more self-confident as a public speaker.
example[21]: She was supremely self-confident, with the gift of being able to talk on any subject whenever the camera was rolling.
definition[5]: confident, calm, and in control of your feelings even in a difficult situation
definition[6]: confident enough to say what you think and want, so that people take notice of you
example[22]: The course helps women learn how to be more assertive in the workplace.
definition[7]: confident that you are right, even when other people do not agree with you
example[23]: He sounded so sure of himself that I didn’t bother to argue.
example[24]: Jenny was younger than her sister but seemed much more sure of herself.
definition[8]: someone who behaves in a confident way in social situations and likes talking and being with other people
example[26]: Jan says her twin babies are completely different: Kelly is a real extrovert while Jessie is quiet and thoughtful.
example[27]: He’s a total extrovert who will talk to any stranger.
definition[9]: to not be confident about your abilities or appearance
example[28]: Francine is lacking in confidence and needs a lot of encouragement.
example[29]: I was fat, had no friends, and lacked confidence.
example[30]: While girls lack confidence, boys often overestimate their abilities.
definition[10]: not confident about meeting or speaking to people who you do not know
example[31]: Jane is a quiet shy person.
example[32]: He had been painfully shy (=very shy) as a child.
definition[11]: not confident about yourself or your relationships, especially because you are worried that you are not good enough
example[33]: His childhood had left him very insecure.
example[34]: Ben’s parents’ divorce left him lonely and insecure.
example[35]: Models can make young women feel insecure about their own bodies.
definition[12]: not confident, especially because you are young or you do not have much experience
example[36]: At first, Chris seemed nervous and unsure of herself.
example[37]: He was only 21 and still very unsure of himself with girls.
definition[13]: not confident that you can succeed, because you have had problems trying to do something
example[38]: Students can become discouraged very easily if they are not given the help they need.
example[39]: I was very discouraged at the time, but I still hoped we could find a solution.
example[40]: Discouraged by her failed marriages, she gradually withdrew from the world.
example[41]: Hartman was so discouraged about the way his performing career was going, that he gave up acting for writing.
definition[14]: someone who is demoralized has lost all their confidence and wants to give up
example[42]: The team were completely demoralized after losing a series of games.
example[44]: Many employees became demoralized and cynical when the company announced another round of job cuts.
